And the comment about the chemistry between Mr. Scott and his wife Claire Forlani, well if you don't have chemistry, you don't have it! It doesn't matter if your married or not.
I'm not a writer so my words may be a little misunderstood.  But when I first came to watch this movie, it was because I saw Dougray Scott in Ever After. Then I looked up the movies he has filmed. I think he is so handsome and intriguing.  His performance in Ever After was amazing. But to my surprise was the fact he is married to Claire Forlani!!! Oh my! I was so happy! I love her! She was amazing in Meet Joe Black! I have to say she is beautiful. Her eyes are captivating! And she is so sweet!
So with that said, I love this movie. This is a movie of love, family, love lost,  and how one deals with carrying out your life after such a horrible situation.  Claire also has a loss if a marraige gone bad, and a father who was not there for her in younger years.
But what impacted me the most was Mr. Scott's love for his wife he lost. It showed his weakness, but yet that weakness was honor and love for his wife lost. It made me cry so much! He is adorable. But when Claire came on the scene it was obvious she captivated him, and he was ready to say goodbye to his first love he lost.

I love British humor! This movie was halarious with its humor here and there. But what is important is if you see the work put into making this movie simple, yet having a heart warming sentiment to it's direction of what the point of it all is.
Life is love, and sometimes loss. It's how we come out of it all in the end. We may not like the things that happen along the way, but it's what you do in the process.
Another observation. It was in the scene where Michelle gets the trifle for the two gentlemen. She is wearing a apron. That apron looks just like the one I have from Portugal.  Curious where it's from.
Lastely,  Mr. Scott and Claire, you are a beautiful couple and I love all your movies.  You have a handsome Scotsman,  and Mr. Scott you have a beautiful wife! Please don't let Hollywood spoil that! Stay in love! Stay together!
I love your movie! And look forward to seeing more of you both in the future!

I bought this DVD on the reputation of Chef Gordon Ramsay from his various reality show series. I am also a fan of Claire Forlani from all the way back when she starred opposite Anthony Hopkins and Brad Pitt in "Meet Joe Black".

My rating is based on the quality of the actors within, as the script is the lowest point of the comedy/melodrama and really needed tossed in the bin (Ramsay speak). Claire Forlani's character shows no interest in cooking or being in the kitchen, and it's a mystery why these people want to be anywhere near a restaurant. I would have preferred had Ramsay had the role as head chef, with Douray Scott working under him and getting yelled at the whole movie for ruining the Beef Wellington.

Special mention for Simon Callow (who played the villain in Ace Ventura When Nature Calls) as Guy Witherspoon, hamming it up with expert precision as an obnoxious and fatuitous restaurant food critic. Actors like Guy Boardman carry the movie, you can see other accomplished talent straining to convey some acting to the consommé-thin soup of a script. Watch it for the actors, and try to forget there are writers like this employed in the movie industry.

Fish, hunt, used to rodeo, but to be honest, hey, yes, I love action packed blood-fest films with large kill-scores and things that blow up but damn, I have to admit, Im also a romantic. Yeah, I was one of those guys who would disguise myself and go off to see every Meg Ryan-Tom Hanks film, and that plethora of Jennifer Anisen, Julia Roberts and Sandra Bullock flicks. I guess because I find them hot, and would just love to accidentally spill coffee on them as Im running down a street, and in the last reel, chase them to the airport where I fall to my knees and ask them to marry me. Now, because of the success of the Food Network, Hollywood is also adding kitchens to the mix. I was once a cook, so that only makes it better. There are a ton of these rom-food films now, most of them rather good. However this one, with one of the worse titles in the last fifty years "Love's Kitchen"  is an abomination. Its made in England, and of course, b being Enlglish myself I think everything from across the pond is better and sometimes thats true. But this was just jaw-dropping bad. It is like the burnt droppings left in the pan that cooked up a Hallmark movie, mixed with something that Lifetime actually threw out, or should I say, threw up. What is stunning is how bad the script is, full of plot holes, and situations that never are tied up. And worse is the direction. I have no idea who this armature is and honestly I have no desire to IMDB him. I mean, he wasted ninety minutes of my time watching his useless drivel, and putting a few minutes into this review, Im not going to take any more time In fact, its not every worth listing his or anyone elses name. There is one wonderful English actor who actually was in some of the top English Rom-coms, playing a TV food critic but he couldn't do a thing to save this, and seems to have walked through this as fast as he could. Its obvious that there was no budget, or if there was, no one, from the DP, to the editor, to basically anyone connect with the film (I mean, I actually noticed how awful the costumes, make-up, sets, etc. were) seemed to give a damn or have the experience or talent to pull off a real live-professional film. Even more astonishing was the food stylist. This is yet another film about a brilliant cook who has dive-bombed, and is brought back by a new women in his life. However, when they try and show him at his best his dishes, and their presentation looks exactly like whats put in front of you at Dennys. No one was thinking. One more thing can we please stop giving our leads that precocious ten-year old daughter? Its either used in rom-coms for heart, or in action films so they get kidnapped. Its getting old. Really, really old. I rented this for something like $2.99 and honestly felt I was robbed! Oh, and there is an American actress in this travesty who should get the award as the 21st Centurys Pia Zadora. I have never, ever seen such an incompetent person trying to act on the screen. Not only cant she show a range of emotion from A to Z, I don't think she can even spell. Truly the worst performance since Pia starred as Girmar in Santa Clause Conquers The Martians.

(No, simply saying CC anymore means that you're relying on the television itself to pick up the captions on the movies, and that does not work anymore with the newer television sets. The DVD itself MUST have subtitles available on the menu for it to be accessible. This is how Hollywood is trying to get around the law of providing close captions for the deaf)

LOVE'S KITCHEN is one of those background movies -something to put on the screen while filing, doing a puzzle, or some other task that needs little attention but an occasional distraction. Written and directed James Hacking, it is a predictable story with a predictable script and put together in a casual way that at least doesn't stir any feathers. Nor does it stir much genuine interest.  It seems like a paste together story for husband/wife team of Dougray Scott and Claire Forlani.

Befuddled Rob Haley (Dougray Scott) was apparently a rising chef in London, put down by food critic Kate Templeton (Claire Forlani), and further distracted by the death of his wife.  In response to the need for change he moves to the country where he finds a pub-like spot in which he decides to create a caf - a truly gourmet spot in the middle of nowhere.  He hires friends to help cook and wait tables.  He garners interest from the townsfolk for his delicious cuisine - especially his 'perfect trifle'.  His efforts do not go unnoticed - Kate Templeton visits, loves the food, and naturally falls in love with Rob... Etc Etc Etc

There is nothing wrong with this bit of British fluff: it just doesn't register on the scale. There are a few sidebars of some note and some cameos by the likes of Simon Callow.  But for the most part this is background entertainment.  Not bad, just background.  Grady Harp, February 12
